thread.title: Who could replace Theresa May as Conservative party leader?

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Who could replace Theresa May as Conservative party leader?
text:
News Who could replace Theresa May as Conservative party leader? Conservatives may face the difficult task of replacing Theresa May as leader. We look at the potential candidates Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Following a “disastrous” election campaign Theresa May’s future is already in doubt. 
The Conservatives are expected to be the biggest party in government but forecasts predict the Tories to fall short of an outright majority needed to govern. 
Mrs May’s performance has already brought criticism from Tory backbencher Anna Soubry who hit out at a “dreadful campaign”. 
Jeremy Corbyn has called for Mrs May to stand down as Prime Minister but as the incumbent ruling party the Tories will have the first shot at forming a coalition. 
Speculation is rife about Mrs May’s future both as Conservative leader and Prime Minister following an election campaign that has fallen far short of the “strong and stable” leadership trumpeted by the leader. 
A number of high-profile Tories lost their seats including former Northern Powerhouse minister James Wharton, Ben Gummer the architect of the Tory manifesto, and former housing minister Gavin Barwell. 
If Mrs May chooses to resign as Conservative leader, or is forced out by colleagues, the party will have to decide who should replace her. 
We’ve taken a look at some of the most likely Conservative candidates to succeed Mrs May, should she leave the post one way or other, some of which will come as no surprise. Who could replace Theresa May? (Photo: PA/Getty) Boris Johnson 
The Foreign Secretary and former London was a favourite to win the Conservative leadership election last year, but surprised supporters by deciding not to stand. 
He still has a lot of support within the party. 
A well-known figure across the country, Boris may be a controversial candidate because of his role as a leading campaigner for Brexit who travelled the country on that infamous bus promising £350 million a week for the NHS. Amber Rudd 
The Home Secretary had a good election campaign, doing well in TV appearances and standing in for Theresa May in one of the televised debates. 
Her problem, though, may be that she won her Hastings constituency with a tiny majority. It means that as leader, she could go in to the net election unsure whether she can retain her seat. Read More General Election 2017 North East results in full: How North East constituencies voted David Davis 
The Brexit Secretary has a blokeish charm. Working class and straight-talking, he could be a good choice. He stood for the Conservative leadership once before, when he was beaten by David Cameron. Michael Fallon 
The Defence Secretary was one of the few Ministers wheeled out to television studios during the campaign. A smooth talker, he may come across as a bit too posh to be leader. Read More
